title: Rowing
text:
Sunrise on Lake Cachuma




My rowing journey began when my old housemate Holden approached me about potentially joining the rowing team. I laughed in jest at his absurd implication that I was somehow a proper fit for the team, a team comprised mainly of 6 foot titans who eat, sleep, and breathe rowing. Holden explained that I could become a coxswain, the individual responsible for barking orders and steering the boat. I’d never saw myself as the type to cox but, given my slim build and ability to project vocally, I thought I’d give it shot.
Eventually, after attending a few practices, I realized how unique of a position I was in. The coxswain sits in the back of the boat facing the eight rowers who are blind to the direction we’re traveling in. As a photographer, I soon saw an opportunity to capture my point of view as, not only a coxswain, but a spectator of the rowing world of which I was novel to.

Waking up at four in the morning five days out of the week wasn’t exactly the most attractive aspect of being part of the team, however, it kept me disciplined in completing my homework in a timely manner. I had not realized how much I relied on staying up late to complete assignments until I couldn’t afford to. Staying up till 12 AM doing homework meant only four hours of sleep before having to get up for practice. Yeah, not happening.
After a few weeks, I was in it. I started working out with the team because a coxswain who trains with their crew gains their trust and maybe some respect. My word was the final say, no ifs, ands, or buts. If I said to keep rowing over a waterfall, they’d better buckle up without a peep. They needed to be able to trust my calls on a dime without any form of hesitation, I needed to be able to trust that they would do what I demanded of them. Building this mutual respect would require showing them that I’m not just sitting pretty in the boat all the time, but that I too am familiar with their pain as we’re barreling towards the finish line with fatigue fully setting in.

It took me a while to get acclimated to the rigor of both the schedule and the training. Since I was a coxswain, I wasn’t required to erg or do the regular training that many of the rowers were required to do. I admired their dedication to putting in the hours of training that they so willingly put in. Erging is not an easy task to simply perform but I suppose that when you get to the level that the rowers were on, you could erg for what seemed like forever. Some would play movies or shows during hour-long erg sessions, maintaining consistency with their pacing and form. I would begin to dwindle after just twenty minutes.

title: Rowing
text:
Competition
My time coxing for the men’s novice 8 was short as I only stayed for Winter and Spring quarters. In my time on the team, I got to experience two instances of real competition. The first is when we faced off against OCC right before spring break of 2024 and the second was later that same year at WIRA: Western Intercollegiate Rowing Association Championship. This was an incredibly nerve-racking experience for me as I was still new to coxing and had never coxed in such an intense environment. We were up against seven other boats, I honestly can’t even remember the place we came in. I just remember how fun it was to see the novice men give it their all in the seven minutes and thirty seconds that it took us to get to the finish line.

title: Rowing
text:
Conclusion
In conclusion, I’m incredibly thankful for my experience on the rowing team. Although I did not get to row, I thoroughly enjoyed experiencing the training and disciplinary aspects that make rowing an infamous college sport. I met many wonderful people who made me feel apart of the team with their willingness to support one another and their drive to be better. It inspired me to be the best cox I could be for the novice men, and even outside of rowing, to be the best version of myself for those around me.





Me on the left, Holden on the right, Sudarshan in the corner.

title: Mark Oregel
text:
My name is Mark Oregel. I’m from Santa Ana, California, and I’m studying Environmental Studies (B.A.) at the University of California, Santa Barbara. I am currently a Garden Operator at the Green House and Garden Project, a community garden located in Isla Vista. I enjoy playing guitar, going on runs, and taking pictures.
My future plans involve going back to school and working towards getting certified in something environmentally related. This can be in the form of an engineering certificate, GIS certification, or even a master’s degree in an environmental field. I really enjoyed the soils classes that I took in my undergrad, and I hope to pursue something related to working with farmers or underprivileged communities to ensure they’re protected from malpractice or exploitation. My goal thus far in my education has been to be able to give back to my community in whatever I end up choosing as a career. I look forward to the coming years after my graduation.

title: GIS: Human Impact on Puma Movement
text: In GEOG 176A - Introduction to GIS, the final project that my group and I chose to work on involved mapping puma movement using tracking-collar data as well as human development in south-central Utah. Our goal was to determine if there was any correlation between areas where there are high amounts of human development, such as railways, buildings, and roads, and puma movement.

title: Focused Environmental Impact Report - Recreational Resources
text: This focused environmental impact report (FEIR) was completed as a result of ENV S 165B Impact Analysis wherein the goal is to complete an FEIR given a hypothetical development scenario. Using the skills we learned in the class, we conducted a site visit and determined environmental impacts of a hypothetical housing development to be located at Campus Point on the UCSB campus. While hypothetical, most aspects of the class were treated as a real scenario. We worked with maps and figures of the proposed development site creating visualizations to convey any and all impacts on our resource of choice. I chose to write about Recreational Resources.

title: Guitars and Music
text:
I started playing guitar in 2023, but really took to it once I moved to Santa Barbara for school. I understand that it’s a cliche to take up the guitar in college, however, I understand why now. Not just the guitar, but certainly playing any instrument is an excellent use of one’s time and energy. In this day and age, it’s so easy to get sucked into your phone or your computer screen. An instrument allows you to disconnect from everything else and plug into something that is difficult and requires you to focus to achieve proficiency. Once you’ve practiced enough, you can begin to express yourself, and I find that really beautiful.
Here are some photos of my guitars:





Ian holding his squier




At a Christmas party in 2012, my cousin Ian (pictured above) approached my brother and I with a guitar in his hands and a Santa beard poorly taped on his face. The guitar was a 2003 Squier Stratocaster and it was the first guitar I’d ever really played. It was actually meant for my brother but he took it to boarding school where it was promptly mounted onto the wall because “it looked cool” and never played. Eventually Eric went to college and, before he could display it in his dorm room once more, I stole it from him on the basis that I would try to learn it. It now leans proudly against an unmounted Smiths poster and next to my computer for when I feel the urge to thrash on it.





Jazz Master B)




Since the summer of 2024 when I lived in IV for summer sessions at UCSB, I was perusing Facebook market place one day and found this awesome Squier Jazzmaster for sale just down the street from me. Two days later and it was leaning right next to my first guitar at the foot of my bed.
I think it’s awesome that I’ve been able to play the guitar that my cousin used to play when he was in a band. There’s something special to me about the idea that I’m playing the same guitar he used to play. I don’t know why, I just can’t shake it.

title: Soils Experience
text:
Digging soil pit #1 during our 3-day Mojave Desert field trip.




Within my undergraduate coursework at UCSB, I had the opportunity to enroll in ENV S 114A - Introduction to Soil Science and ENV S 114B - Soils of California. These classes, instructed by Iris Holzer, allowed me to get my hands dirty both metaphorically and literally. 114A was an introduction to soil classification, properties, and its connection to many other fields of environmental studies. While this was a very informative class on its own, I chose to pursue soil further in taking 114B the following winter quarter. I can safely say that this is one of the best decisions I could’ve made as far as choosing coursework. In 114B, we deep-dived into soil classification learning, not only how to classify a wide range of soils, but also the methodology and practices that contribute to safe and fun field work for my peers and I. These two courses were truly the highlights of my senior year experience at UCSB and stand as a true testament to the value of hands-on learning and experience outside of the classroom.

title: ENV S 193DS: Coding Work
text:
Data Wrangling and Calculations
The next code chunk contains the code necessary to wrangle the specific data columns that I want to use for my analysis. I created another object and selected the ‘Long Day’ and ‘Money Spent’ columns and calculated the average money spent on long days. I then created another object titled ‘average_money_summary’ which I used to create a group using the ‘Long Day’ data. I then summarized calculations of mean money spent, standard deviation, standard error, and the upper and lower quartiles. Lastly, I rounded the values to one decimal place.

# creating `average_money_summary` before so R can read it in order to render 
money_spent_long_day <- ActiveData1 |> # creating new object from 'ActiveData1' to 'money_spent_long_day'
  select(`Long Day`, `Money Spent`) # selecting `Long Day` and `Money Spent` 

average_money_summary <- money_spent_long_day |> # create new object from `money_spent_long_day` to `average_money_summary` 
  group_by(`Long Day`) |>  # grouping by `Long Day` points 
  summarize(mean = mean(`Money Spent`), # summarizing the mean from `Money Spent` 
            sd = sd(`Money Spent`), # calculating the standard deviation from `Money Spent` 
            se = sd / sqrt(n()), # calculating standard error from standard deviation 
            ci_lower = mean - qt(0.975, df = n() - 1) * se, # calculating the upper and lower quartile 
            ci_upper = mean + qt(0.975, df = n() - 1) * se) |> 
  
  
  mutate(across(c(mean, sd, se, ci_lower, ci_upper), # round mean, sd, se, ci upper and lower to one decimal place 
                ~ round(.x, 1)))

title: ENV S 193DS: Coding Work
text:
Creating a Table
The following code chunk expresses the information that was calculated above but in a table format where I changed the labels to reflect the information displayed.

average_money_summary |> # start with average_money_summary
  gt() |> # calling in the 'gt' table function 
  cols_label( # labeling the different aspects of the table by their full names
    `Long Day` = "Long Day",
    mean = "Mean",
    sd = "Standard Deviation",
    se = "Standard Error",
    ci_lower = "95% Confidence Level (Lower)",
    ci_upper = "95% Confidence Level (Upper)"
    
  ) |> 
  tab_header(title = "Money Spent Summary Statistics") # setting the title as "Money Spent Summary Statistics"

title: ENV S 193DS: Coding Work
text:
Visualizing the Data
The following code chunk contains the code needed to make a visualization of my personal data along with the calculations that I made earlier (standard deviation, standard error, upper and lower quartiles). I started by using the data object that I created earlier to create underlying data set while placing my original data (ActiveData1) over it. I also added an error bar displaying the standard error and mean.

ggplot(data = average_money_summary, # starting with data frame 
       aes(x = `Long Day`, # label x-axis as 'Long Day'
           y = `mean`, # label y-axis as 'mean' 
           fill = `Long Day`)) + # fill color for 'Long Day' variable 
  geom_jitter(data = ActiveData1, # use jitterplot function starting with 'ActiveData1' data frame 
              aes(x = `Long Day`, # set x-axis as Long Day for jitterplot 
                  y = `Money Spent`, # set y-axis as Money Spent  
                  color = `Long Day`), # use color for Long Day variable
              shape = 18, # setting open circle for shape 
              alpha = 1, # setting transparency 
              size = 2, # setting size of points 
              height = 0, # disabling vertical jitter points 
              width = 0.1) + # enabling horizontal jitter points 
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = mean - se, # creating errorbar and creating the upper and lower edges of the standard error 
                    ymax = mean + se),
                width = 0.1, # setting width of the caps
                color = "black" # setting color to black 
                ) + 
  geom_point(data = average_money_summary, # adding primary data frame to display on top of the previously displayed data 
             aes(x = `Long Day`, # setting x-axis as 'Long Day'
                 y = `mean`), # setting y-axis as mean money spent   
             inherit.aes = FALSE, # seperating new aesthetics from the previous aesthetics 
             color = "black", # setting color to black for mean point 
             size = 2) + # setting size to 2 
  theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white"), # filling background with white to disable panels 
        panel.grid.major = element_line(color = NA), # disabling major panel lines 
        panel.grid.minor = element_line(color = NA), # disabling minor panel lines 
        legend.position = "none", # disabling the legend from showing up 
        axis.line = element_line(color = "black")) + # setting color of axis lines to black 
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Yes" = "dodgerblue", # setting color of 'yes' money points to dodgerblue 
                                "No" = "firebrick")) + # setting color of "no" money points to firebrick 
          
  # manually setting title to 'Money Spent on Campus with Standard Deviation and Standard Error', adding subtitle to 'By Mark Oregel', changing y-axis name to 'Money Spent (dollars)', changing x-axis name to 'Long Day'. 
  labs(title = "Money Spent on Campus with Standard Deviation and Standard Error",
       subtitle = "By Mark Oregel",
       y = "Money Spent (dollars)",
       x = "Long Day") 









Caption:
This jitter plot displays a comparison of money spent on campus between long and short days. Each point represents a daily observation with the red and blue dots indicating individual spending. The black points represent the group means and the error bars show the standard error of the mean.
